elements.content: Reactions of La­(NO3)3·6H2O with the polar, tritopic quaternized carboxylate ligands N-carboxymethyl-3,5-dicarboxylpyridinium bromide (H3CmdcpBr) and N-(4-carboxybenzyl)-3,5-dicarboxylpyridinium bromide (H3CbdcpBr) afford two water-stable metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) of {[La4(Cmdcp)6(H2O)9]} n (1, 3D) and {[La2(Cbdcp)3(H2O)10]} n (2, 2D). MOFs 1 and 2 absorb the carboxyfluorescein (FAM)-tagged probe DNA (P-DNA) and quench the fluorescence of FAM via a photoinduced electron transfer (PET) process. The nonemissive P-DNA@MOF hybrids thus formed in turn function as sensing platforms to distinguish conservative linear, single-stranded RNA sequences of Sudan virus with high selectivity and low detection limits of 112 and 67 pM, respectively (at a signal-to-noise ratio of 3). These hybrids also exhibit high specificity and discriminate down to single-base mismatch RNA sequences.

elements.content: The two La-based MOFs 1 (3D) and 2 (2D) have been constructed and characterized. MOFs 1 and 2 absorb the carboxyfluorescein (FAM)-labeled probe DNA (P-DNA) to form a P-DNA@MOF sensing system with fluorescence quenching. The formed nonemissive P-DNA@MOF hybrids subsequently function as biosensors to detect the conservative linear, single-stranded RNA sequences of Sudan virus with high selectivity and detection limits at the picomolar level. The hybrids also exhibit high specificity and discriminate down to single-base mismatch RNA sequences.

elements.content: Ebola virus (EBOV) is a human epidemic associated with four subspecies, namely Bundibugyo virus (BDBV), Reston virus (RESTV), Sudan virus (SUDV), and Taï forest virus (TAFV). Among these viruses, SUDV induces a 50% fatality rate and longer progression to death. SUDV is a filamentous RNA virus that causes Ebola viral hemorrhagic fever (VHF), which is severe and often fatal to human and nonhuman primates. Unfortunately, there is currently no effective drug or vaccine for this type of virus. Thus, early diagnosis of such an RNA virus is essential for its surveillance and control.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Ebola virus (EBOV) is a human epidemic associated with four subspecies, namely Bundibugyo virus (BDBV), Reston virus (RESTV), Sudan virus (SUDV), and Taï forest virus (TAFV). Among these viruses, SUDV induces a 50% fatality rate and longer progression to death. SUDV is a filamentous RNA virus that causes Ebola viral hemorrhagic fever (VHF), which is severe and often fatal to human and nonhuman primates. Unfortunately, there is currently no effective drug or vaccine for this type of virus. Thus, early diagnosis of such an RNA virus is essential for its surveillance and control.

elements.content: Efforts have been made to develop fluorescence assays for nucleic acid detection. The general mechanism used in such an approach lies in the absorption of the fluorophore-labeled single-stranded probe DNA (denoted as P-DNA) by a nanomaterial to form a conjugate, accompanied by substantial fluorescence quenching. Following the specific hybridization with its target disease-related DNA or RNA sequences, the formed double-stranded DNA, DNA@RNA, or triplex DNA becomes more rigid and detaches from the surface of the nanomaterial with the recovery of fluorescence. Up to now, a handful of nanomaterials, including gold nanoparticles, single-walled carbon nanotubes, and graphene, have been successfully used in this assay, and most of these nanomaterials are able to detect DNA or RNA at the nanomolar level.

elements.content: Metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have recently emerged as platforms for the detection of target DNA and RNA, and studies have been largely focused on well-established MOFs, including MIL-101, MIL-88B, and UiO-66-NH2. We recently found that MOFs of zwitterionic carboxylate ligands showed good water stability. Several such MOFs based on first-row transition-metal ions were exercised as sensing platforms to detect Ebola and HIV virus RNA or DNA sequences. To further explore such potential and expand the metal scope to lanthanides, we herein report a three-dimensional (3D) MOF of {[La4(Cmdcp)6(H2O)9]} n (1; H3CmdcpBr = N-carboxymethyl-3,5-dicarboxylpyridinium bromide) and a 2D MOF of {[La2(Cbdcp)3(H2O)10]} n (2; H3CbdcpBr = N-(4-carboxybenzyl)-3,5-dicarboxylpyridinium bromide) () for the formation of sensing platforms and further for the detection of SUDV sequences. Lanthanides are good candidates for this particular purpose because of their high oxophilicity and high coordination number to make water-stable and structurally intriguing MOFs.

elements.content: MOF 1 is porous, and the edges of its channel are embroidered with positively charged quaternary ammonium nitrogen atoms, while MOF 2 demonstrates a 2D layer structure with aromatic rings, positively charged pyridinium and La­(III) ions, and free carboxylates on its surface. These structural characteristics contribute to the interactions of MOFs 1 and 2 toward P-DNA to form conjugates as sensing platforms. These two sensing platforms show good detection performance toward SUDV sequences at the picomolar level and discriminate RNA sequences down to single-base mismatch.

elements.content: The ligands H3CmdcpBr and H3CbdcpBr were prepared as reported. Other reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet MagNa-IR 550 infrared spectrometer. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on an SDTA851 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min–1 under N2. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectra were collected from a Rigaku D/max2200/PC instrument. The X-radiation pumped (voltage 40 kV, current 40 mA) from a sealed Cu tube was monochromated through a graphite crystal and collimated by a 0.5 mm MONOCAP (λ­(Cu Kα) = 1.54178 Å). An LS55 spectrofluorimeter was used to collect fluorescence and fluorescence anisotropy data. The average particle sizes and the ζ potential measurements of 1 and 2 were analyzed with a Zetasizer NanoZS90 instrument. SEM images were collected on a Hitachi S-4800 FESEM instrument with an accelerating voltage of 3.0 kV. CO2 adsorption isotherms were carried out using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Surface Area and Porosity Analyzer. Different concentrations of MOF 1 or 2 with probe DNA (P-DNA) were investigated with circular dichroism (CD, Chirascan plus ACD).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

The ligands H3CmdcpBr and H3CbdcpBr were prepared as reported. Other reagents and solvents were obtained from commercial sources and used without further purification. IR spectra were recorded on a Nicolet MagNa-IR 550 infrared spectrometer. Elemental analyses for C, H, and N were performed on an EA1110 CHNS elemental analyzer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on an SDTA851 thermogravimetric analyzer with a heating rate of 10 °C min-1 under N2. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) spectra were collected from a Rigaku D/max2200/PC instrument. The X-radiation pumped (voltage 40 kV, current 40 mA) from a sealed Cu tube was monochromated through a graphite crystal and collimated by a 0.5 mm MONOCAP (λ(Cu Kα) = 1.54178 Å). An LS55 spectrofluorimeter was used to collect fluorescence and fluorescence anisotropy data. The average particle sizes and the ζ potential measurements of 1 and 2 were analyzed with a Zetasizer NanoZS90 instrument. SEM images were collected on a Hitachi S-4800 FESEM instrument with an accelerating voltage of 3.0 kV. CO2 adsorption isotherms were carried out using a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 Surface Area and Porosity Analyzer. Different concentrations of MOF 1 or 2 with probe DNA (P-DNA) were investigated with circular dichroism (CD, Chirascan plus ACD).

elements.content: The DNA sequences were commercially available from Sangon Inc. (Shanghai, People’s Republic of China) and the RNA sequences from TaKaRa (Dalian, People’s Republic of China). These target conservative sequences of SUDV RNA sequences are as follows: T20:, 5′-GAU­GAG­GAC­AAA­CUU­UUU­AA-3′; T30, 5′-UCU­UCC­GUU­UGA­UGA­GGA­CAA­ACU­UUU­UAA-3′; T40, 5′-AUG­AUG­GUG­AUC­UUC­CGU­UUG­AUG­AGG­ACA­AACU­UUU­UAA-3′.

elements.content:
The complementary sequence for T20 as probe DNA (P-DNA) is as follows: 5′-FAM-TTA­AAA­AGT­TTG­TCC­TCA­TC-3′

The single-base mismatch for target RNA T20 (T1) is as follows: 5′-GAU­GAG­GAC­ACA­CUU­UUU­AA-3′

The scrambled nonspecific RNA for target RNA T20 (T2) is as follows: 5′-GGC­AAU­CAG­CUG­GAC­ACA­UG-3′

All of the sequences were dissolved in Tris-HCl buffer solution (100 μM, pH 7.4, 100 mM NaCl, 5 mM MgCl2). DNA was stored at 4 °C and RNA at −80 °C for use. All of the instruments used for the detection of Sudan virus RNA sequences were sterilized in an autoclavable container.

elements.content: H3CmdcpBr powder (45.8 mg, 0.15 mmol) was suspended in MeOH (15 mL), and 4.5 mL of NaOH (0.1 M) was added to give a clear solution. A solution of La­(NO3)3·6H2O (43.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) in MeOH (1.5 mL) was then introduced and the mixture stirred for 30 min. The white precipitates that formed were collected by filtration, washed with MeOH (5 mL), and redissolved in H2O (30 mL) at room temperature to give a clear colorless solution. When the solution stood at ambient temperature for about 2 weeks, colorless needle crystals of MOF 1 were formed (44.0 mg, 86%). Anal. Calcd for C54H48N6O45La4·2H2O (1·2H2O): C, 30.98; H, 2.49; N, 4.02. Found: C, 30.85; H, 2.39; N, 3.98. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): ν 3424 (s), 2355 (w), 1649 (s), 1612 (s), 1384 (s), 1238 (w), 1178 (w), 774 (w), 724 (m), 623 (m), 526 (m).

elements.content: The crystallographic measurement was made on a Bruker APEX II diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) irradiation for 1 and 2. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects with the SMART suite of programs and for absorption effects with SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the SHELXTL-97 program. In MOF 1, the coordinates of the hydrogen atoms on the coordinated H2O were suggested by the Calc-OH program in the WinGX suite; their O–H distances were further restrained to O–H = 0.85 Å and thermal parameters constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). However, for MOF 2, the hydrogen atoms on the coordinated H2O solvates were not located. In both 1 and 2, an amount of spatially delocalized electron densities in the lattice were found but acceptable refinement results could not be obtained for these electron densities. The solvent contributions were then modeled using SQUEEZE in the Platon program suite. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) as supplementary publication numbers 1486699 and 1486700. A summary of the key crystallographic data for 1 and 2 are given in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. The selected bond distances and angles for MOFs 1 and 2 are given in Tables S2 and S3 in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Crystal Structure Determinations for 1 and 2 

The crystallographic measurement was made on a Bruker APEX II diffractometer by using graphite-monochromated Mo Kα (λ = 0.71073 Å) irradiation for 1 and 2. The data were corrected for Lorentz and polarization effects with the SMART suite of programs and for absorption effects with SADABS. The structure was solved by direct methods and refined on F 2 by full-matrix least-squares techniques with the SHELXTL-97 program. In MOF 1, the coordinates of the hydrogen atoms on the coordinated H2O were suggested by the Calc-OH program in the WinGX suite; their O-H distances were further restrained to O-H = 0.85 Å and thermal parameters constrained to U iso(H) = 1.2U eq(O). However, for MOF 2, the hydrogen atoms on the coordinated H2O solvates were not located. In both 1 and 2, an amount of spatially delocalized electron densities in the lattice were found but acceptable refinement results could not be obtained for these electron densities. The solvent contributions were then modeled using SQUEEZE in the Platon program suite. Crystallographic data have been deposited with the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center (CCDC) as supplementary publication numbers 1486699 and 1486700. A summary of the key crystallographic data for 1 and 2 are given in Table S1 in the Supporting Information. The selected bond distances and angles for MOFs 1 and 2 are given in Tables S2 and S3 in the Supporting Information.

elements.content: MOFs 1 and 2 were synthesized in 86% and 80% yields from the reaction of La­(NO3)3·6H2O with deprotonated pyridinium carboxylate. Powders of MOFs 1 and 2 were placed in H2O at room temperature and sonicated for 2 h to give a solution, which was kept for 48 h and then centrifuged at 30000 rpm for 20 min. The solid that was collected was dried at room temperature. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of these recollected samples of 1 and 2 are in agreement with those of the simulated patterns, confirming the bulk phase purity and H2O stability for both MOFs (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). SEM micrographs show that MOFs 1 and 2 form nanoparticles with a certain degree of agglomeration (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information) show that the radius was 404.1 ± 8.3 nm for 1 and 346.2 ± 9.2 nm for 2, suggesting that both MOFs show good dispersion in H2O. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) indicate that the frameworks of samples of 1 and 2 are collapsed beyond 300 °C (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Synthesis and Characterization of MOFs 1 and 2 

MOFs 1 and 2 were synthesized in 86% and 80% yields from the reaction of La(NO3)3⋅6H2O with deprotonated pyridinium carboxylate. Powders of MOFs 1 and 2 were placed in H2O at room temperature and sonicated for 2 h to give a solution, which was kept for 48 h and then centrifuged at 30000 rpm for 20 min. The solid that was collected was dried at room temperature. The powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns of these recollected samples of 1 and 2 are in agreement with those of the simulated patterns, confirming the bulk phase purity and H2O stability for both MOFs (Figure S1 in the Supporting Information). SEM micrographs show that MOFs 1 and 2 form nanoparticles with a certain degree of agglomeration (Figure S2 in the Supporting Information). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements (Figure S3 in the Supporting Information) show that the radius was 404.1 ± 8.3 nm for 1 and 346.2 ± 9.2 nm for 2, suggesting that both MOFs show good dispersion in H2O. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) indicate that the frameworks of samples of 1 and 2 are collapsed beyond 300 °C (Figure S4 in the Supporting Information).

elements.content: MOF 1 crystallizes in the hexagonal space group P31 c, and its asymmetric unit contains one Cmdcp ligand, two coordinated H2O molecules in which one has half occupancy and one has full occupancy, and three individual La ions in which two have one-sixth occupancy and one has one-third occupancy. The 3D structure of MOF 1 (a) can be better understood as being supported by 1D chains running along the c axis. The 1D chain, in turn, is composed by alternate linking of La3+ ion (La1) and a linear trimetallic cluster (La2 and La3). As shown in Figure S5a in the Supporting Information, the La1 ion is associated with nine oxygen atoms from three H2O molecules at the belt plane and six monodentate carboxylates evenly distributed as two pairs with respect to the belt plane and ready to associate with the surface La ions (La3) from a pair of adjacent linear trimetallic clusters (Figure S5b). Within the trimetallic cluster, the central La2 ion is chelated by six carboxylates in a chelating-bridging fashion and thus has a rare coordination number of 12. The six carboxylates further extended to a pair of symmetrical La3 ions (b). Thus, each surface La ion (La3) is coordinated by three oxygen atoms from three carboxylates (connected with La1) in a monodentate fashion, three oxygen atoms from three chelating-bridging carboxylates, and three H2O molecules to give a nine-coordinate coordination fashion, similar to that observed for La1.

The 3D structure of MOF 1 (a) can be better understood as being supported by 1D chains running along the c axis. Within the trimetallic cluster, the central La2 ion is chelated by six carboxylates in a chelating-bridging fashion and thus has a rare coordination number of 12. elements.content: The 3D network MOF 1 possesses large circular channels that are filled with guest H2O. The approximate diameter of the circular channel, calculated considering the van der Waals surface, is around 15.0 Å. The potential solvent-accessible void turns out to be 1421 Å3, which occupies 32% of the unit cell volume.
elements.clean_text: The 3D network MOF 1 possesses large circular channels that are filled with guest H2O. The approximate diameter of the circular channel, calculated considering the van der Waals surface, is around 15.0 Å. The potential solvent-accessible void turns out to be 1421 Å3, which occupies 32% of the unit cell volume.

elements.content: MOF 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, and the asymmetric unit consists of one [La2(Cbdcp)3(H2O)10] molecule. The La centers are linked by a pair of μ-COO groups and a single μ-COO group alternatively in a −[double–single] n – chain fashion (). Each La center is further coordinated to one monodentate carboxylate from one Cbdcp ligand. The other carboxylate of this Cbdcp ligand is connected to the neighboring chain as the single μ-COO group, thereby forming a 2D structure within the ac plane. The remaining carboxylates are free and deprotonated to balance the positive charge of the pyridinium cations and La­(III) centers. In MOF 2, each La­(III) has a monocapped-square-antiprismatic coordination geometry with the coordination of nine oxygen atoms from three μ-COO carboxylate groups, one monodentate carboxylate group, and five H2O molecules.
elements.clean_text:
Crystal Structure of {[La2(Cbdcp)3(H2O)10]} n  (2)

MOF 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c, and the asymmetric unit consists of one [La2(Cbdcp)3(H2O)10] molecule. The La centers are linked by a pair of μ-COO groups and a single μ-COO group alternatively in a -[double-single] n - chain fashion (). Each La center is further coordinated to one monodentate carboxylate from one Cbdcp ligand. The other carboxylate of this Cbdcp ligand is connected to the neighboring chain as the single μ-COO group, thereby forming a 2D structure within the ac plane. The remaining carboxylates are free and deprotonated to balance the positive charge of the pyridinium cations and La(III) centers. In MOF 2, each La(III) has a monocapped-square-antiprismatic coordination geometry with the coordination of nine oxygen atoms from three μ-COO carboxylate groups, one monodentate carboxylate group, and five H2O molecules.

elements.content: Brunauer–Emmett–Teller (BET) surface areas of 156 and 113 m2 g–1 were estimated from CO2 sorption data at 195 K (Figure S6 in the Supporting Information). Integrating highly charged La3+ ions, cationic pyridinium centers, conjugated π electrons, and coordinated and free carboxylates on the surface, MOFs 1 and 2 are capable of interacting with aromatic nucleotide bases in the FAM-labeled, negatively charged probe DNA (P-DNA, on-state) and quenching the FAM fluorescence (off-state) via photoinduced electron transfer (PET). Therefore, we have studied the interactions of MOFs 1 and 2 with FAM-labeled P-DNA 5′-FAM­TTA­AAA­AGT­TTG­TCC­TCA­TC-3′, a complementary sequence of SUDV RNA. As shown in , the quenching efficiencies of 1 and 2 to P-DNA are 70.2 ± 5.3% and 57.3 ± 5.3%, with saturated concentrations of 45 and 40 μM, respectively. Thus, MOFs 1 and 2 can both quench the photoluminescence of the P-DNA due to the formation of P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2 systems. The results show that 1 has a higher quenching efficiency in comparison to 2. We hypothesized that this is likely due to the exposure of positively charged quaternary ammonium centers at the edge of the larger surface area of 1 that provide a stronger electrostatic interaction with P-DNA. To verify such a hypothesis, we calculated the binding affinities of 1 and 2 toward P-DNA. The binding constant is inferred from the double logarithm given in , where F 0/F denote the fluorescence intensities at 518 nm in the absence/presence of the MOF, K b denotes the binding constant, and n denotes the number of binding sites. The binding constants between MOFs 1 and 2 with P-DNA are 3.0 × 104 and 1.5 × 104 M–1, respectively, which coincide with their quenching efficiency. log ( F 0 − F ) / F = n log [ compound ] + log ⁡ K b

elements.content: To further explore the key contributing factors that cause the fluorescence quenching, we analyzed the quenching efficiency of each individual component (H3CmdcpBr, H3CbdcpBr, and La­(NO3)3) at varying concentrations. As shown in and Figure S7 in the Supporting Information, the quenching efficiencies of La­(NO3)3, H3CbdcpBr, and H3CmdcpBr to P-DNA are 79.8 ± 6.4%, 8.3 ± 2.4%, and 7.5 ± 1.9% with saturated concentrations of 60, 30, and 30 μM, respectively, indicating that La3+ ion plays a major role in the quenching process. It should be noted that, as also discussed in the following section, though La3+ ion itself exhibits a better quenching efficiency than both MOFs 1 and 2, the FAM fluorescence cannot be recovered in the presence of the target RNA likely due to the strong coordination between the P-DNA and La3+ to give a stable coordination complex.

elements.content: Subsequent inclusion of the respective complementary target SUDV RNA sequences in the P-DNA@1 or P-DNA@2 system results in a stable DNA@RNA duplex. The formation of the duplex serves to keep the P-DNA away from the surfaces of MOFs 1 and 2, leading to the fluorescence recovery (on-state). Thus, the sensing capabilities of P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2 systems for SUDV RNA sequences were evaluated by the fluorescence regeneration induced by the addition of complementary SUDV RNA sequences (5′-GAU­GAG­GAC­AAA­CUU­UUU­AA-3′, T20). We found that the fluorescence intensity recovery is time-dependent. The fluorescence intensity increased with incubation time and remained unchanged when the incubation time was longer than 30 ± 5 min for P-DNA@1 and 18 ± 2 min for P-DNA@2 with a T20 concentration of 25 nM for both systems (Figure S8 in the Supporting Information). The longer recovery time of P-DNA@1 in comparison to that of P-DNA@2 is probably due to adsorption of the P-DNA by the pores of 1, which prohibits its effective recombination with target RNA sequences. However, for P-DNA@2, the flat surface of 2 lowers the steric hindrance and favors target–probe hybridization. In addition, increasing the concentration of target SUDV RNA sequences led to a gradual increase in the fluorescence intensity until saturation was observed at a concentration of 50 nM for both P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2 (). Under this condition, the fluorescence intensities of P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2 show the anticipated linear relationships with the concentration of the target RNA sequences (inset of ) and give detection limits of 112 pM with an RSD of 1.2% and 67 pM with an RSD of 1.1%, respectively.

elements.content: To investigate the specificity of P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2 toward T20, we analyzed two kinds of RNA sequences, a single-base mismatch for RNA T1 (one A base in the middle of T20 was replaced with C) and a scrambled nonspecific T2, to hybridize with P-DNA in the two systems. As shown in and Figure S9 in the Supporting Information, the introduction of completely complementary target Sudan virus RNA T20 results in marginal fluorescence enhancement, with the recovery efficiency (R E) approaching 0.62 ± 0.03 for P-DNA@1 and 0.78 ± 0.02 for P-DNA@2, which was calculated according to the equation R E = F T/F M – 1. In sharp contrast, the R E values are only 0.03 for T1 and 0.02 for T2 with the P-DNA@1 system and 0.02 for T1 and 0.01 for T2 with the P-DNA@2 system under the same experimental settings. In addition, the fluorescence recovery induced by T20 shows much higher concentration dependence in comparison to that by T1 and T2 (). These results collectively suggest that the formed sensing platforms are highly selective toward the target SUDV RNA sequences.

elements.content: Sequence T20 is part of the complete Sudan virus genome (GenBank No. AF173836.1) that has 2926 nucleotides in length. Therefore, in order to further evaluate the practical application of P-DNA@1 or P-DNA@2 in the detection of SUDV RNA sequences, we extended the length of target SUDV RNA sequences from 20 (T20) to 30 (T30) and 40 (T40) nucleobases. As shown in , introducing T30 and T40 to both systems also results in decent fluorescence enhancement with R E values being 0.49 and 0.37 for P-DNA@1 and 0.63 and 0.50 for P-DNA@2. Under these conditions, the detection limits are 806 pM for T30 and 1016 pM for T40 of the P-DNA@1 system and 83 pM for T30 and 92 pM for T40 of the P-DNA@2 system. These observations suggest that the recovery efficiency decreases as the length of the target RNA sequence increases. In addition, using a single-base mismatch for target T40 (RNA T40A) as interfered RNA sequences gives a drastic decrease in R E values of 0.01 for both systems, pointing to the high selectivity of the sensing systems.

elements.content: The above results show that P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2 are efficient and selective sensing platforms for SUDV RNA sequences. Such results may be rationalized from the structural traits of MOFs 1 and 2. The ζ potentials of MOFs 1 and 2 are +3.1 and +3.6 mV, respectively, indicating that they are positively charged. With the conjugated π-electron system in MOFs and aromatic nucleotide bases in the probe DNA, 1 and 2 absorb P-DNA through electrostatic and π-stacking interactions to form P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2 hybrids and quench the fluorescence of the FAM via a PET process. In the fluorescence recovery step, the channel size of 1 and the large surface of 2 play critical roles in effectively distinguishing P-DNA from DNA@RNA duplex. As shown in Figure S10 in the Supporting Information, almost no change in the circular dichroism (CD) data of P-DNA was observed when it was incubated with MOF 1 or 2, corroborating that the conformation of P-DNA exhibits no change in the presence of MOFs. Further by comparison of the diameters of the circular channel (15.0 Å) of 1 and the tag of FAM in P-DNA (9.4 Å), we speculated that the single-strand moiety of P-DNA having a smaller cross-sectional area but larger conformational flexibility in comparison to duplex DNA@RNA should be able to “induce fit” to enter the pore or, for MOF 2, form close interactions with the surface through multiple interactions. Furthermore, MOFs 1 and 2 exhibit less affinity toward DNA@RNA duplex due to the significant reduction of unpaired bases as well as the rigid conformation of the latter. Therefore, the competitive hybridization of T20 with the absorbed P-DNA would lead to the ejection of the FAM-labeled P-DNA from MOF 1 or 2 as a DNA@RNA duplex, resulting in the recovery of FAM fluorescence. This argument is supported by the alteration of the fluorescence anisotropy (FA), an indicator of rotational motion-related factors of the P-DNAs, P-DNA@T20 (hybrid duplex) before and after the inclusion of 1 or 2. As shown in , adding 1 or 2 to the P-DNA leads to an increase in the fluorescence anisotropy by 0.25 or 0.21, whereas addition has a negligible influence on the P-DNA@T20. This result reveals the exclusively stronger interaction of MOFs 1 and 2 with the P-DNA in comparison to that with hybrid DNA@RNA duplex.

elements.content: We further carried out agarose gel electrophoresis to evaluate the sensing system. As shown in , P-DNA displayed one emissive band and such a band is absent upon its incubation with MOFs 1 and 2, suggesting that P-DNA is able to integrate with 1 and 2 to yield P-DNA@1 and P-DNA@2, which are too large to pass through the gel. Once T20 was introduced into the system, the mixture gave two light bands. One band represents the DNA@RNA duplex which moved more slowly due to its higher molecular weight, while the other represents the excess T20. The identities of these two bands were verified by adding P-DNA to a solution containing excess T20. In such a case, a bright and slower band corresponding to the duplex and a light and faster band corresponding to the remaining excess T20 were observed. These experiments collectively support that MOFs 1 and 2 are able to distinguish P-DNA from DNA@RNA duplex and thereby verified our proposed mechanism.

elements.content: We have demonstrated that La-based 3D and 2D MOFs are suitable platforms to support efficient and selective SUDV RNA sequence sensing with high selectivity and sensitivity. From a structural perspective, the use of multidentate carboxylate ligands bearing an sp3 methylene group generally lowers the symmetry of ligands, such as ligands H3CmdcpBr and H3CbdcpBr reported herein. Using low-symmetry ligands to complex with a high coordination number of Ln ions (such as 12-coordinate in MOF 1) can effectively compensate the irregularity of the ligands to form high-dimensional networks. These results encourage us to further design sensing platforms from MOFs with larger pore sizes or larger surfaces to hybridize with longer P-DNA sequences, thus allowing the detection of much longer SUDV RNA sequences. One of our future incentives is to design longer carboxylate ligands bearing quaternary ammonium centers to achieve 3D MOFs with high porosity and large surface areas.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

We have demonstrated that La-based 3D and 2D MOFs are suitable platforms to support efficient and selective SUDV RNA sequence sensing with high selectivity and sensitivity. From a structural perspective, the use of multidentate carboxylate ligands bearing an sp3 methylene group generally lowers the symmetry of ligands, such as ligands H3CmdcpBr and H3CbdcpBr reported herein. Using low-symmetry ligands to complex with a high coordination number of Ln ions (such as 12-coordinate in MOF 1) can effectively compensate the irregularity of the ligands to form high-dimensional networks. These results encourage us to further design sensing platforms from MOFs with larger pore sizes or larger surfaces to hybridize with longer P-DNA sequences, thus allowing the detection of much longer SUDV RNA sequences. One of our future incentives is to design longer carboxylate ligands bearing quaternary ammonium centers to achieve 3D MOFs with high porosity and large surface areas.

cln_elements.content:
H3CmdcpBr powder (45.8 mg, 0.15 mmol) was suspended in MeOH (15 mL), and 4.5 mL of NaOH (0.1 M) was added to give a clear solution. A solution of La­(NO3)3·6H2O (43.3 mg, 0.1 mmol) in MeOH (1.5 mL) was then introduced and the mixture stirred for 30 min. The white precipitates that formed were collected by filtration, washed with MeOH (5 mL), and redissolved in H2O (30 mL) at room temperature to give a clear colorless solution. When the solution stood at ambient temperature for about 2 weeks, colorless needle crystals of MOF 1 were formed (44.0 mg, 86%). Anal. Calcd for C54H48N6O45La4·2H2O (1·2H2O): C, 30.98; H, 2.49; N, 4.02. Found: C, 30.85; H, 2.39; N, 3.98. IR (KBr disk, cm–1): ν 3424 (s), 2355 (w), 1649 (s), 1612 (s), 1384 (s), 1238 (w), 1178 (w), 774 (w), 724 (m), 623 (m), 526 (m).

Synthesis of {[La<sub>2</sub>(Cbdcp)<sub>3</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>10</sub>]}<sub> <italic>n</italic> </sub> (<bold>2</bold>)

A solution of H3CbdcpBr (114.6 mg, 0.3 mmol) in H2O (50 mL) was adjusted to pH 6.0 with 0.1 M NaOH solution. A solution of La­(NO3)3·6H2O (86.6 mg, 0.2 mmol) in H2O (50 mL) was then added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 100 °C for 0.5 h to give a clear solution.
